com.cyc.kb.wrapper

Class AssertionWrapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.cyc.kb.wrapper.KbObjectWrapper
      • com.cyc.kb.wrapper.AssertionWrapper
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Assertion, KbObject, KbObject.KbObjectWithArity
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FactWrapper, RuleWrapper

    public abstract class AssertionWrapper
extends KbObjectWrapper
implements Assertion
    An abstract base class for implementing Assertions per the decorator pattern. To use, extend this class and implement the wrapped() method to return the wrapped object.

      • getContext

        public Context getContext()
        Description copied from interface: Assertion
        the context associated with the assertion. The assertion is true in this and any context that inherits this context.
        Specified by:
        getContext in interface Assertion
        Returns:
        the context of the assertion NOTE: Even though we have the assertion object, when we try to retrieve a context, we could still not find it, if the object is "stale". Currently we do not synchronize the API objects with the KB. This method throws a runtime exception if it couldn't find the context.

      • getSupportingAssertions

        public Collection<Assertion> getSupportingAssertions()
                                              throws KbTypeException,
                                                     CreateException
        Description copied from interface: Assertion
        the collection of assertions that directly support this assertion. For assertions that are not deduced, the collection will be empty. An assertion can be "asserted assertion", that is, asserted locally by a cyclist. Or an assertion can be "deduced assertion", that is, the inference engine has justification to believe that the sentence is true in a given context. A deduced assertion has one or more independent arguments (justifications) supporting the assertion. A deduction is a type of argument for an assertion. Assertion by a cyclist is also an argument. A deduction has multiple "supports", some of these supports are due to HL modules and others may be asserted or deduced assertions. This method returns the "asserted assertions" that support the deductions, supporting this assertion.
        Specified by:
        getSupportingAssertions in interface Assertion
        Returns:
        a set of supporting assertions
        Throws:
        KbTypeException
        CreateException

      • isDeducedAssertion

        public Boolean isDeducedAssertion()
        Description copied from interface: Assertion
        Returns true if this assertion is supported by other assertions, false if this assertion is not deduced from anything else. Note that an assertion can be both a deduced assertion and an asserted assertion at the same time.
        Specified by:
        isDeducedAssertion in interface Assertion
        Returns:

      • delete

        public void delete()
            throws DeleteException
        Description copied from interface: Assertion
        Remove this Assertion from the KB. It should be noted that deleting an Assertion from the KB does not mean that the information contained in that that assertion will necessarily become unknown to Cyc. For example, there are many cases where an Assertion may be asserted but also be easily inferable. In those cases, the Assertion will no longer be represented in Cyc as a separate assertion, but Cyc's inference system will continue to behave as if it were present in the KB because it is easily inferable.

        There are also cases where Assertions can not be deleted. The most prominent of these cases is when the underlying assertion has been forward deduced from some other assertion(s). In such cases, the only way to remove the Assertion is to remove enough of the assertions it is deduced from, to prevent it from being inferred (e.g from Assertion.getSupportingAssertions()). As a general rule of thumb, if you assert something to the Cyc KB, you will also be able to delete it. And you can also delete the vast majority of assertions that were already present in the KB. Extreme care should be taken when deleting Assertions that you didn't create, since the process of deletion destructively modified the KB, and deleting facts that Cyc critically relies on may cause it to behave in erratic ways.

        Specified by:
        delete in interface Assertion
        Throws:
        DeleteException - when the underlying assertion can't be removed from the KB.

      • getArity

        public Integer getArity()
        Description copied from interface: KbObject.KbObjectWithArity
        Returns the syntactic arity of this object. If it has a getRelation applied to some arguments (i.e. it's a Sentence, an Assertion, or a functional term), the arity is the number of arguments. By convention, Cyc constants have a formula arity of 0.
        Specified by:
        getArity in interface KbObject.KbObjectWithArity
        Returns:
        the arity of this object, null if not a Cyc constant, functional term, Sentence, or Assertion

      • getArgument

        public <O> O getArgument(int argPosition)
                  throws KbTypeException,
                         CreateException
        Description copied from interface: KbObject.KbObjectWithArity
        Gets the object in argPosition argument position of this KbObject as an object of type O. This method works for Sentences and Assertions, as well as non-atomic KbTerms. However, because a constant has no "arguments", calling this method on a KbObject representing a Cyc constant will result in a KbException.
        Specified by:
        getArgument in interface KbObject.KbObjectWithArity
        Type Parameters:
        O - the object type
        Parameters:
        argPosition - the argument position of the object returned
        Returns:
        the object at getPos as a O
        Throws:
        KbTypeException
        CreateException

      • addComment

        public Fact addComment(String comment,
                       Context ctx)
                throws KbTypeException,
                       CreateException
        Description copied from interface: Assertion
        Add a new comment for this in the context specified

        In the CycKB comments can be added only on #$CycLIndexedTerms, which include CycLReifiableDenotationalTerm and CycLAssertion. An exception will be thrown if attempted to add a comment on Quoted terms, Sentence, Variable and Symbol. This means that only subclasses of KbTerm and Assertion can have comments.

        Specified by:
        addComment in interface Assertion
        Parameters:
        comment - the comment string
        ctx - the context where the comment is created. Cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the fact created
        Throws:
        KbTypeException
        CreateException

      • addQuotedIsa

        public Assertion addQuotedIsa(KbCollection collection,
                              Context context)
                       throws KbTypeException,
                              CreateException
        Description copied from interface: Assertion
        A quotedIsa assertion relates CycL expression to SubLExpressionType.

        All subclasses of KbObject can be quoted. Refer to #$NoteAboutQuotingInCycL for a more detailed discussion of quoting.

        Specified by:
        addQuotedIsa in interface Assertion
        Parameters:
        collection - the instance of SubLExpressionType, the collection this is a quoted instance of
        context - the context where the fact is asserted.
        Returns:
        this KbTerm, for method chaining
        Throws:
        KbTypeException
        CreateException
